criteria: Identification of Organisms and Abiotic Components
descriptions: Does not identify organisms or abiotic components in the ecosystem.
Identifies only organisms or only abiotic components, but not both.
Identifies some organisms and abiotic components, but with significant omissions or inaccuracies.
Identifies most of the significant organisms and abiotic components in the ecosystem with minor inaccuracies.
Identifies nearly all significant organisms and abiotic components accurately.
Accurately and comprehensively identifies all significant organisms and abiotic components, demonstrating a thorough understanding of their roles.
Fails to describe any interactions between organisms in the ecosystem.
Describes a single type of interaction (e.g., predation) with limited detail.
Describes multiple types of interactions, but lacks depth or accuracy.
Describes several key interactions (competitive, predatory, mutually beneficial) with reasonable accuracy.
Provides detailed and accurate descriptions of competitive, predatory, and mutually beneficial interactions.
Offers comprehensive and insightful descriptions of interactions, including their complexities and nuances within the ecosystem.
Does not attempt to predict any interaction patterns.
Attempts a prediction, but it is illogical or unsupported by evidence.
Predicts patterns with limited justification or understanding of cause-and-effect relationships.
Predicts interaction patterns based on some evidence, but the explanation lacks depth.
Clearly predicts interaction patterns based on evidence and explains cause-and-effect relationships.
Predicts interaction patterns accurately, thoroughly explains cause-and-effect relationships, and extends the prediction to other ecosystems.
Demonstrates no awareness of environmental principles.
Mentions one environmental principle vaguely.
Mentions multiple environmental principles but does not connect them to the ecosystem.
Connects some environmental principles to the functioning of the ecosystem, but the connections are superficial.
Connects multiple environmental principles to the ecosystem, explaining how human actions influence ecosystem health.
Deeply integrates environmental principles, thoroughly explaining how human societies and natural systems interact, and proposes solutions for sustainability.
